Blood Death Knight.note: As Deathbringer, use on cooldown; as San'layn, hold for  Dancing Rune Weapon.

Another passive damage trinket, with an on-use that allows you to "recycle" its procs into a decently large Strength buff. As San'layn, use it during  Dancing Rune Weapon. As Deathbringer, use it while  Reaper's Mark is ticking.
Currently bugged and not subject to the 33% tank tax. It oversims in that any stacks left on target at time of death is damage that could have been dealt.
While it is in  "The 50 Verses of Resilience", you gain a very small amount of bonus armor and a small chance to gain a very small absorb shield when you take non-periodic damage
As San'layn, use with  Dancing Rune Weapon.
As San'layn, use right before  Dancing Rune Weapon. You will be holding its cooldown for a small amount of time between uses due to its 90 second cooldown.

A completely passive trinket that simply deals damage to your target and everything nearby when you reach 10 stacks. The proc chance is hasted, and so San'layn will get massively more value out of this during  Dancing Rune Weapon.

The performance of this trinket really depends on the fight length. Every 15 seconds, you gain a stack of  Infuriated the next time you take damage, and this also grants you a relatively small absorb shield. Both values are multiplied by your total number of stacks at the time.This decays slowly while out of combat, losing a stack every ~5 seconds.
Use a weakaura to track when this trinket's buff expires, and bind to a friendly target of your choice when it does. The choice of secondary is not that important, but all four options are simmable.

Provides a stacking Strength buff made of individual stacks, each lasting a minute. The proc chance is hasted and stacks persist out of combat, making it significantly better for Mythic+ than for raid.
Completely passive trinket; you simply gain stats every now and then.
As blood, you will frequently trigger the additional effect of this trinket, gaining more value than you would otherwise. This is what propels this to A-tier.
Provides a larger than normal Strength bonus at the cost of some secondaries once per minute.
Grants a large amount of mastery roughly once per minute, with much higher value in Mythic+ due to stacks granted by enemy deaths. This gets better the lower the key level, too!
A pretty boring stat proc trinket. Underwhelming, particularly seeing the competition.

An underwhelming direct-damage on use, and the prime example that the 33% tank role penalty on trinkets makes little to no sense. Use it until you find better, and simply use it on cooldown until then.

A completely passive trinket whose value increases as the fight goes on. Unlike other trinkets of this type, the damage amplification is a debuff on the target, meaning that this loses value for Mythic+.
Completely passive trinket that grants some strength and damage. It is mostly underwhelming, but not a total write-off.

This trinket triggers every minute, and its duration can be roughly doubled by dealing critical strikes. As Blood has a relatively large number of damage events every second, as long as you do not ignore critical strike (you shouldn't!), you can easily get the full value out of this trinket.

Use on cooldown on the target with the largest number of stacks at the time. This loses value in Mythic+, since you will not be able to have every stack on the same target and will likely not be able to guarantee that a target nearby has 5 stacks.
Serves no real purpose; this reduces damage dealt by a target by a small amount, applying after absorbs and damage reduction.

Frost Death Knight.note: Our strongest passive trinket option provides a large amount of one of our preferred stats. The proc spawns an orb that drifts towards you, giving you a small measure of control over when you start the buff.

A stronger on-use option that excels in AoE content. Be aware that it has a channel time and should be used before Pillar of Frost to avoid wasting GCDs. This trinket will excel in Mythic+, but is not preferred as much in raid content due to a lack of opportunity to stack the Critical Strike buff against multiple targets.

One of our best on-use options this season, despite it not perfectly lining up with our cooldowns. Although the strength buff decays, it decays over a longer duration than Pillar of Frost's duration. By the time the buff decays to its low point, we have already gotten the benefit when we need it most.

Frost loves Critical Strike, so it is no surprise to see a trinket with a Critical Strike proc near the top of the list. Frost has plenty of passive damage sources that can critically hit to get the maximum duration.

An interesting passive trinket, particularly in Mythic+. It procs a debuff with a long duration that slowly ramps up the damage, ensuring you cannot drop stacks and that it retains value on long fights. Much of the value is tied up in having targets available to absorb the final explosion, so this trinket struggles in raid.

Our best on-use trinket this season. The stacking buff gives us high flexibility for buffing our cooldowns. In a patchwerk scenario, we can use this paired with every Pillar of Frost but the first. If we want to save up for a late lust, we can do that too.
A purely passive damage proc trinket. You might use one if you get it early at a high item level, but otherwise would ignore it.
A damage proc that has nothing special going on. The proc spawns at a random point near you and then fires a line through your target. The proc rate is relatively low, and it cannot be aimed.
A visually impressive on-use trinket, but it has nothing we want. It only adds flat damage, and the lack of primary stat means the damage needs to be absurdly powerful.

This one might look unappealing from its cover, but it performs surprisingly well in its class. It keeps up with the other solid Delve trinkets in single-target and will be even better in AoE encounters.

Early on in the season, this will be a bad use of  Spark of Starlight and not worth crafting. However, later in the season, this is an acceptable alternative if you have a surplus of  Spark of Starlight.

Unholy Death Knight.note: A rather potent proc trinket, and among the best for Unholy. In single-target scenarios, it is very close between pacemaker and astral antenna, though in other scenarios it loses out to Void Touched Fragment.

Vengeance Demon Hunter.note: This trinket provides consistent main stat as well as secondary. It will give your selected ally 20% of the stats that it gives you, and the stat you gain is based on their highest stat. Ideally you will choose someone with haste, crit, or vers. Due to the group bonus, it is one of the strongest group trinkets, while providing equivalent personal stats to our other best options.

This trinket provides static Crit. As long as you can stay in combat, this trinket does an absurd amount of damage and shielding, but dropping combat is a huge loss. It is very strong for progression as well as if you can stay in combat in Mythic+. Once you drop combat, you lose one stack roughly every 3 seconds, so staying in combat is crucial if playing this trinket.

This trinket has no baseline effect, but deals damage passively when you press abilities. Every 10 seconds, it stacks power up to 18 times, and when used, it consumes all stacks to grant a large amount of Agility. Its strength lies in its flexibility, since it grants slightly less stat than  Araz's Ritual Forge every 2 minutes, but can be used on any vulnerability phases, rather than being forced to sync it up.
Radiance mode: Grants some Critical Strike and your attacks have a chance to deal bonus Holy damage.

This trinket provides a static Haste gain. It has a 2.5 RPPM proc that spawns an egg which will hatch after a minute and deal damage as well as granting main stat. The buff can stack and you can have multiple spiderlings at once as well.

This trinket provides a static Haste gain and a 1.5 min CD which grants yourself and 4 nearby allies (your entire party in M+) a 75% damage reduction shield with quite a large cap. This is actually a healer-spec only trinket, but it drops in raid so you can have someone trade it to you.

Grants a 15 second Critical Strike buff on the first ability used every minute, extending by 1 second from any critical hits up to a maximum of 30 seconds. This should almost always have maximum uptime, given that we tend to have a good amount of Critical Strike.

This trinket grants Agility and has a 1 min CD on-use that grants a 50% damage reduction shield, as well as dealing a pitiful amount of damage. This is the best option for  Aldrachi Reaver players if a defensive trinket is needed, but it is generally worse than  Ringing Ritual Mud.

This trinket is simply a raw damage trinket which deals a massive amount of damage in longer fights due to not having the 33% tank penalty applied to it, but it has Mastery baseline which we generally don't prefer. However, it's quite a bit weaker in M+ due to fading when the target dies rather than exploding.

The on-use effect grants a good amount of your highest Secondary stat for 20 seconds on a 2 minute cooldown. Additionally, has a minor benefit for any allies also using the trinket. Syncs up well with  Metamorphosis for large burst. It's your second strongest AoE burst trinket as  Fel-Scarred when lined up with  Metamorphosis and if your highest secondary is Crit. For  Aldrachi Reaver it is decent with haste as your highest secondary, but not quite as strong.

This trinket grants Agility and has a 1 min CD on-use that grants a 50% damage reduction shield, as well as dealing a pitiful amount of damage. This is the best option for  Aldrachi Reaver players if a defensive trinket is needed, but it is generally worse than  Ringing Ritual Mud.

This trinket has no baseline effect, but deals damage passively when you press abilities. Every 10 seconds, it stacks power up to 18 times, and when used, it consumes all stacks to grant a large amount of Agility. Its strength lies in its flexibility, since it grants slightly less stat than  Araz's Ritual Forge every 2 minutes, but can be used on any vulnerability phases, rather than being forced to sync it up.

This trinket grants Agility consistently, and a 2.5 RPPM proc that deals a large amount of damage to the target. If there are any enemies stacked nearby, they also split 50% of the damage dealt to the primary target. Additionally, this trinket gains 2% damage for every 1% health missing on the target, so it can deal up to 3 times normal damage if the target is nearly dead.

This trinket provides a static Agility gain. It has a 1.5 minute CD on-use which deals damage and grants a decent amount of Crit on-use. However, it grants more Crit per enemy hit up to ~20 enemies, which more than doubles its value in large pulls. It is generally weaker than other stat trinkets on lower target counts.

This trinket provides static Agility. It has a 2.5 RPPM proc that generates an orb that will slowly move towards you and needs to be walked over to be picked up. Each orb grants a large amount of Crit for a very short period, so it's both annoying to use and requires too much attention for min-maxing gains compared to other stat trinkets.

This trinket grants static Haste. It has a 2 minute on-use that deals a fairly large amount of split damage, which can be useful for certain burst scenarios, but there aren't really any of those this season.
This trinket just grants Agility and a 1.55 RPPM proc of any secondary. It's decent, but falls behind most other stat trinkets due to being random and not always our preferred stats.
This trinket grants Agility and a 2 RPPM proc which deals split damage in a line. It's decent damage, but really nothing else.

This trinket grants Agility and a 10 RPPM proc which grants a stacking debuff. At 10 stacks, you gain a large amount of haste, but it can also proc off kills, making it fairly decent despite being a Delve trinket.
This trinket grants Agility and a low chance on damage taken to grant Versatility. The proc rate isn't high enough for it to be good, and it comes from delves which are lower item level.

This trinket has static Agility and 1.66 RPPM to summon an orb that can either explode on enemies for split damage, or you can reposition to soak it for a Mastery buff. It doesn't do much damage and we don't love Mastery, so it's not particularly great.
This trinket grants static Agility and a chance to lifesteal, dealing some damage over time and healing you for that amount. It's from delves, so it's not particularly strong.

This trinket grants Agility and a 2 minute on-use that deals damage and grants your lowest stat. It's stronger against Ethereals, since it will grant your highest secondary instead, but it's not great.
This trinket grants Agility and a 4 RPPM proc that deals damage in a DoT. If the enemy dies, you gain Vers, but it's not a lot.

This trinket grants Agility and a 10 RPPM proc that will spawn fragments. With 15 fragments, you gain a very large Mastery buff. Additionally, enemies that die will drop Fragments, so it can have quite high uptime in Mythic+. However, it's Mastery, so we don't really want it.

The only cheat death trinket this tier. It actually grants Agility as well as a fairly strong proc upon taking damage, but the cheat death portion is bugged and doesn't properly trigger off the threshold, so it can sometimes kill you when you would have lived otherwise. If this gets fixed, it will be very strong.

This trinket grants static Crit. It additionally has a 2 RPPM proc that deals damage and debuffs the enemy, causing them to take more damage each time it procs. If they die, they deal AoE damage based on the number of times they were hit. While interesting in concept, in practice most of the damage gets wasted, the radius of damage is miniscule, and the proc rate isn't high enough to balance it out.
This trinket grants Agility and a 6 RPPM proc which reduces all damage you take for a few seconds. Unfortunately, the damage reduction is extremely small so it's not particularly good.
This trinket grants Agility and has a 1.5 min CD on-use that grants a decent amount of Mastery. Unfortunately we don't want that.

This trinket grants Agility and speed. It has a 1.5 RPPM proc that drops 2 bombs that you need to run into to deal AoE damage at your target, but you only have 10 seconds when they spawn, and it forces repositioning, making it hot garbage.
This trinket grants static Mastery and a 2 minute on-use that drops an AoE which damages enemies and heals you per target hit. It's quite weak.
Not only does this trinket grant Stamina, but the 1 RPPM damage reflect is absolutely pitiful. We take so little damage nowadays that this performs strictly worse than any other available trinket.

Another Stamina trinket, this grants a 2 RPPM proc that deals a tiny amount of damage and grants a small shield whenever we avoid an attack. It's absolutely awful and nearly as bad as not wearing a trinket at all.
This trinket grants Agility which is its only saving grace. It has a 3 RPPM effect that grants leech when taking damage, which is just useless.

Balance Druid.note: Strong effect that you can grant to another party member, benefitting you both, but there are better options that suit Affliction.

Restoration Druid.note: Just ok by itself but also powers up the powerful raid effect weapons. When paired it becomes a must-use trinket, when not paired it's B-tier.
A unique and powerful Mythic+ trinket that puts a massive shield on every member of your group.
You might not use an on-use trinket this tier but if you do then the Ritual Forge is a good one with its long duration matching our healing well.
A slightly overbudget stat stick. Slightly high variance but we also benefit well from the passive Haste on it. Does not require you to cast DPS spells.
A high uptime stat stick. The crit proc is a little weak for us but the trinket still does well overall.
The strongest stat stick this tier since it has 100% uptime and also gives a friend a buff. You can also pick which stat it gives you.
This is a good stat stick but Crit is a criminally bad stat for us in raid. A fine Mythic+ trinket however.

Puts a debuff on an ally every 30s, when you direct heal them they'll get an absorb for the overhealing that specific healing event does. Sadly this is quite underbudget so it'll probably only see niche use.
Can be combined with every second Flourish but likely to give us haste which we don't want a burst of at the end of our ramp window.
Another split focus trinket that just fails to do much with either strength. Not awful.
An on-budget mastery stat stick that just loses out to other high value stat sticks.
Summons a lot of Sprites that'll follow you around casting absorbs. Better when the overall healing requirement is low.
A fairly disappointing back up option if you can't get any of the above trinkets. Very high variance.
A 1:30 trinket is difficult for us to leverage well.
Medichopper attempts to be both an absorb and ally buff trinket and does neither job well despite multiple tuning passes.
High variance and not our preferred stat.
Drops a comically large void circle that heals allies inside for a small amount.

Devastation Evoker.note: Strong effect that you can grant to another party member, benefitting you both, but there are better options that suit Devastation.

Preservation Evoker.note: An overbudget stat stick. Will summon orbs that slowly float toward you. You can run into them to get the buff early or just wait for them to hit you.
Not a great trinket alone, but when combined with any of the raid Effect weapons it comes very good since it gives them a significant buff.
An excellent Mythic+ trinket that gives a massive absorb to your group. Only average in raid where you'd rather have something that offers more raw stats.
Can be combined with every Stasis. A clear choice if you want an on-use trinket for a fight and fills a similar role to House of Cards in Season 2.
You'll have noticed this tier has a ton of generic stat sticks in it. This is one of the better ones with high uptime.
The best stat stick on offer this tier since it both gives you a stat of your choice and offers a small buff to an ally. The real advantage here is that it's 100% uptime.

Puts a debuff on a random ally every 30s. When you direct heal them (with Echo or Spiritbloom) it'll give them a shield purely for the value of that one single healing event, and then give you an intellect buff. Can be lined up quite well with our burst windows but is very difficult to play well.
Not a bad trinket but we can do better than passive haste and a high variance proc. Slightly better in Mythic+ but there are more reliable alternatives on offer.
Quite decent in the hands of a newer player but once you're experienced you'd really prefer something that gives you more stats than this awkward hybrid.
A bang average stat trinket that does offer one of our best stats.
A high variance stat stick. You might seek one out if you don't plan on doing Raid or Mythic+ content.
Summons Sprites that will follow you around shielding you.
A fairly disappointing back up option if you can't get any of the above trinkets. Very high variance.
Just doesn't line up very well with anything for us making it both difficult to use and worse than alternatives.
Difficult to line up with any of our heavy hitting abilities. Fine as an early pickup until you get better.
Medichopper spends its budget trying to do two things and as a result it's not very good at either job.
A comically bad trinket option. If you have Season 2 trinkets they will all beat this. It might also lose to trinkets you still have from last expansion.
Drops a fairly large circle that covers up mechanics for little gain. Arguably a net loss.

Beast Mastery Hunter.note: Costs a  Spark of Starlight. so not generally a recommended craft. Comes with a small buff to healing potions.

Survival Hunter.note: To be really honest, it cannot quite compete with  Araz's Ritual Forge, but it is the next best option for an on-use trinket to pair with your cooldowns, and it is farmable!

Very similar to  Astral Antenna, but it has a much more consistent nature. This is a bit of a double edged sword however, part of  Improvised Seaforium Pacemaker's value is that it syncs with our cooldowns naturally, but if you have to delay your cooldowns for any reason it may end up proccing outside of your cooldowns for a bunch of the encounter. This will frequently occur in M+, but it may also occur during raid encounters where you are holding your cooldowns for a little bit.

Very similar to  Astral Antenna, but it has a much more consistent nature. This is a bit of a double edged sword however, part of  Improvised Seaforium Pacemaker's value is that it syncs with our cooldowns naturally, but if you have to delay your cooldowns for any reason it may end up proccing outside of your cooldowns for a bunch of the encounter. This will frequently occur in M+, but it may also occur during raid encounters where you are holding your cooldowns for a little bit.

Drops down a few tiers because its channel is on the Global Cooldown, meaning it is going to take away some other ability you could have pressed instead. This is unlike other trinkets and sadly the trinket is too weak to make up for this. Even in a best case (aoe) scenario, it struggles to with other on-use trinkets such as  Lily of the Eternal Weave. If you do find yourself using this, treat it as if it were a 2 minute cooldown, unless the encounter ends before then.
To be really honest, it cannot quite compete with  Araz's Ritual Forge, but it is the next best option for an on-use trinket to pair with your cooldowns, and it is farmable!
A fairly decent stat stick, but its random nature can occasionally proc less desirable stats. Either way, the overall stats it does provide have a very decent uptime

A neat little proc trinket, Aiming it isn't too bad for us considering we already naturally position ourselves in such a way as part of our rotation. Its damage isn't amazing but it does add up for sure.

A decent passive stat stick, but it can be somewhat limited by the availability of stats within your group or raid. There is no guarantee anyone in your party has mastery to pick from. If you're more of a solo player there is no one to use the trinket on.
The lack of Agility as a static stat on this trinket makes it lose some value for us, it certainly is a decent trinket but there are better, more consistent options out there.

One of the few delve trinkets that may be worth chasing. At 710 it easily competes with a 710 signet. Even though it will for the most part end up giving you versatility, in some more niche scenarios it will most likely end up giving mastery. The raw damage it deals is mostly just a bonus!
Neat little damage trinket with some execute bias, but sadly its damage falls short of stat sticks for us. Doubly so when AoE is involved.

Generally there are much better trinkets to craft. Spending a spark on this would be unwise especially considering there are much better trinkets to obtain from repeatable sources. With that said, if you truly have no other uses for your sparks it can fill some gearing gaps.

With a psuedo dynamic on use cooldown, it can line up with all of our available cooldown timers (45s, 90s, 120s). However, it doesn't perform extremely well, its lack of passive stats means the on-use effect needs to be incredibly powerful to make up for the lack of stats, And while it is strong, it isn't powerful enough to push it into the upper tiers.

Perhaps a little callback to  Beacon to the Beyond? Either way, it works quite similar. This time around however,  Perfidious Projector isn't as powerful. This is partially because we really, really prefer having a stat on-use trinket to amplify our cooldowns.
Ideally, you should be intercepting most of the orbs, but this may not always be feasible. If you do, it can serve as a decent little stat stick trinket.

Drops down a few tiers because its channel is on the Global Cooldown, meaning it is going to take away some other ability you could have pressed instead. This is unlike other trinkets and sadly the trinket is too weak to make up for this. Even in a best case (aoe) scenario, it struggles to with other on-use trinkets such as  Lily of the Eternal Weave. If you do find yourself using this, treat it as if it were a 2 minute cooldown, unless the encounter ends before then.

Arcane Mage.note: A strong passive trinket. There's no playing around this; just equip it and forget it!
Another strong passive, there's a lot of these.
Strong passive, make sure you sim the various verisons of this so you can target the right ally to get the best stats!
Another good use trinket to use with  Arcane Surge.
Solid on-use option when used after  Arcane Surge.
A good use trinket to use after  Arcane Surge.
Use with  Arcane Surge, make sure you don't get stunned!
A solid on-use trinket. It's just held back by being lower maximum item level.
Another passive option, there's a lot of these equip-and-forget trinkets.
Essentially a passive trinket that you have to click to get the benefit from. Prioritize using this so long as it won't interfere with you using a steroid trinket with your cooldowns with stacks.

Fire Mage.note: Strong effect that you can grant to another party member, benefitting you both, but there are better options that suit Fire.
Haste trinket with a damage proc. The effect is Single Target.
Passive damage over time proc. If a target dies with this DoT active, you gain Versatility.

Frost Mage.note: You need to collect the orbs that spawn and chase you to gain stats. If you are using this, you may need to drop a lot of Critical Strike rating from the rest of your gear.
This is generally the most powerful on-use trinket in Season 3, but be careful not to kill yourself since it deals damage to you when you use it.
This is a powerful passive trinket when combined with the set weapons. You can also lower your mana using  Arcane Explosion before combat to take better advantage of this trinket.
This is a strong on-use stat trinket. Despite giving Mastery, it's still quite strong for both hero talent trees.
This is a strong passive stat trinket.
This is a strong passive stat trinket.
This is a strong passive stat trinket.
This is a strong passive stat trinket. You can use this on allies to choose which stat it gives you, which lets it easily fill gaps in your gear.
This is a simple passive damage trinket.
This is a decent passive trinket, but it can get a little weak if you have too much Mastery, since it doesn't scale with that stat.
If you need to craft a trinket, this is the only one available.
This trinket does a bunch of burst damage when you use it, but it's generally quite undertuned.

Brewmaster Monk.note: Once every 90 seconds, you may activate the trinket to immediately force it to switch buffs and double the current effects (both the stat and proc) for 20 seconds.

An alternative to  Lily of the Eternal Weave, this trinket's 2-minute cooldown is better suited to Master of Harmony Brewmasters who are more likely to have a longer  Weapons of Order cooldown. Fortunately, it will provide your favorite secondary (likely Versatility or Critical Strike) while also giving a small amount of it to any other players with the same trinket equipped as well!

Mistweaver Monk.note: On its own, this trinket is fairly lackluster, offering us our worst secondary stat and a decent Intellect buff. But when combined with one of the set weapons attached with it, it becomes incredible. Increasing the efficacy of the  Shards of the Void effect by as much as the set bonus does is ridiculous, and should be one of our highest priority grabs.

This trinket is great for  Invoke Yu'lon, the Jade Serpent focused builds. A static amount of Intellect for a baseline increase to our throughput, while the effect increases our Critical Strike. While different instances of the buff can overlap rather than refresh the duration, having a loosely consistent increase to Critical Strike while we're awash in Haste rating is fantastic.

Similar to  So'leah's Secret Technique above, this instead takes that static amount of a secondary stat and increases it in an on-use effect that we'll want to pair with each use of whichever August Celestial we're deciding to invoke.

Similar to  So'leah's Secret Technique above, this instead takes that static amount of a secondary stat and increases it in an on-use effect that we'll want to pair with each use of whichever August Celestial we're deciding to invoke.

This trinket is one of the best trinkets for an  Invoke Chi-Ji, the Red Crane build, being able to increase our Intellect at the start of his duration, when we have a high count of  Teachings of the Monastery stacks to immediately send in a  Blackout Kick. The loss of health when we use this is negligible, especially if we cast that first  Enveloping Mist on ourself. In  Invoke Yu'lon, the Jade Serpent builds, this is far weaker because the healing that Yu'lon does is spread throughout her entire duration, making this trinket lose a lot of potential value. It's ranked an A+ as a compromise between both builds.

This trinket, while it doesn't have a static amount of Intellect for our overall throughput, the on-use effect it has more than makes up for it. A baseline amount of Haste is always welcome for a specialization as hungry for a single stat as Mistweaver is, and the effect it has is phenomenal for both Mythic+ and raid encounters. The only thing better than healing up damage is preventing it entirely, and this manages to do both, reducing incoming damage by a large percent until a ceiling is met, and any left over absorb is used to heal allies around that damage-free player.

Baseline amount of Haste makes this a little weaker than other trinkets that have a static amount of Intellect, but the effect makes up for it! Just paly as normal and you'll be gaining enough Intellect to realize the strength of this trinket.

Static amount of Intellect good. The remaining power of this trinket being spread between all four secondary stats is...fine. If this trinket increases your Mastery, it's a nice little increase to your throughput, but we really want any of the other three stats at this point in the expansion. Haste is great, Critical Strike and Versatility increase all aspects of our throughput. The former stats gives us more throughput per stat rating while increasing our mana thanks to the critical strike effect of  Mana Tea, while the latter stats also gives us some damage reduction.

Static Intellect is great, and the stacking Critical Strike effect is...fine. The way to gain them is a bit difficult for Mistweavers compared to other classes that are able to equip this, seeing as it's based on spell-flagged casts and ranged abilities, which we have few of as it is, let alone ones we wish to be casting with any regularity.

Very much the baseline of trinkets. Base amount of Versatility, with a buff that increases our Intellect. The additional effect of mana potions being stronger is great for early progression where we're still getting a feel for fights and figuring out when we're safe to drink our  Mana Tea stacks.

The best trinket from Season 2, holding on quite strongly in the face of other trinkets that have substantially more item level behind them. The static amount of intellect and the very good effect make keep this trinket relevant as we acquire more gear at the start of this new season.

A trinket with a foundation of Intellect with a healing effect tied to it. Healing an ally that's near others grants you Haste, but because the chance for this effect to activate isn't under our control, it leaves a little to be desired with the strength of this trinket.

One of the stronger Delves trinkets, this has a static amount of Versatility and a healing effect that attempts to give us full value, as any overhealing it does is converted into an absorb shield. Pretty basic trinket that suffers in these rankings without any Intellect.

Another fantastic trinket from the prior season, the static amount of Intellect this gives us, combined with its Critical Strike effect, keep it relatively high among new competitors, but we will see it drop off as the season progresses.

Returning from the past season, this trinket gives a solid amount of Intellect, while also allowing us to shield an ally that we'll be healing consistently to try and gain the on-use effect again and again.

Windwalker Monk.note: This trinket is so oppresively strong, even after a 10% nerf, that you will talent out of Xuen's Bond and align your cooldowns with it, rather than aligning it with your cooldowns.
The best trinket in single target and a strong contender in multi-target, making it the strongest passive trinket in Raids and #1 or #2 in Mythic+.
If Ritual Forge wasn't so incredibly strong, this would be the best on-use trinket. It is the strongest 90-second trinket which syncs well with the Conduit cooldown windows.
This is the Spymasters-style trinket for melee. Generally it is very strong, but mileage may vary.
Strong passive trinket, just not quite strong enough to make it to S tier.
The randomness hurts this trinket, but it is quite strong even still.
Probably the strongest passive trinket in Mythic+, but only slightly, and loses decently to the stronger single target focused trinkets.
Great in single target, not great in dungeons.
A strong trinket, but nowhere near as strong as Ritual Forge, and not strong enough to make you not play Xuen's Bond, so it becomes a 3-minute trinket.
Strong single target, but no AOE to speak of.

Holy Paladin.note: A simple stat proc trinket. It procs crit and has a good uptime.
On its own, this trinket would be closer to B-tier, but once you combine it with  Voidglass Sovereign's Blade, it becomes Best-in-slot.
A passive stat stick trinket. Simply use it on another player to get a bit of their highest stat. Ideally use it on someone who has Haste or Mastery as their highest stat.
An on-use trinket that should be used with your  Avenging Wrath every 2 minutes.
Not a powerful trinket for raw throughput in raids, but it can have some very strong use cases in Mythic+ as an extra defensive for your group.
This trinket is very overbudgeted if you can get it to proc consistently. It only procs from DPS spells, so in Raid it will have worse uptime than in Mythic+.
Should be used with  Avenging Wrath every 2 minutes. When you use it, it deals damage 15% of your health as damage to you, so be careful!
A decent option if you are having issues getting any of the better trinkets at max item level. Is has decent uptimes and makes your potions stronger.
An interesting trinket on paper, but it is sadly just tuned a little on the low side. You need to heal the person that gets the debuff directly to proc it.

Protection Paladin.note: This trinket doesn't provide any baseline Primary or Secondary stats. It switches between two states: One that increases armor and one that increases Critical Strike. The switching mechanic itself can happen in two ways, the first of which is when you get hit. There is a hidden counter with a 750 ms internal cooldown where you gain stacks of whatever state you're in until you hit 50 stacks. After this, the trinket will automatically swap to the other state. The other way to swap states is to activate the on-use effect, which will swap you to the other state instantly.Speaking of the buffs themselves, the Critical Strike buff is more valuable than the armor buff. We already have a lot of armor as is, and gaining another small amount is less valuable than it might appear.The best way to use this trinket is to activate the on-use effect whenever you are in the armor buff state to instantly swap to the Critical Strike buff state.
This is a strong stat stick that excels in AoE and Mythic+.

Decent on use absorb trinket that has reduced CD if you are afflicted with periodic effects. There are a few periodic effects this coming Raid tier, which make this trinket more sought after than previously.

Retribution Paladin.note: On use Strength trinket. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes.
Passive Crit proc trinket. You'll need to run into the orbs it spawns to gain its effect.
Passive Crit proc trinket. No special usage required.
Passive Strength and DoT proc. No special usage required.
On use secondary stat buff. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes.
Passive damage proc. No special usage required.
On use damage trinket that also provides a secondary stat buff. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes.
Passive damage proc. No special usage required.
Passive secondary stat buff trinket. You'll need to use it on a player to gain its effect.
On use Crit buff. It requires a short channel, so use it before your regular cooldowns.
On-use Strength stat buff. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes.
Passive DoT effect. No special usage required.
Passive damage proc. No special usage required.
Passive damage proc. No special usage required.
Passive Strength proc. No special usage required.

Shadow Priest.note: Strong effect that you can grant to another party member, benefitting you both, but there are better options that suit Affliction.

Assassination Rogue.note: By far the strongest trinket in the entire patch and entire expansion so far,  Araz's Ritual Forge stands alone above any other alternative for 2 min on-use trinkets.

In our next tier down,  Astral Antenna still sticks out as a great trinket. The only issue is that players will need to pick up a small purple orb in order to receive the effect. The orb naturally floats towards you, so it's not overly intrusive.
Lily of the Eternal Weave is looking to be the 90s trinket of choice this upcoming patch, which is relevant to us due to the tier set bonus on Fatebound.

This trinket is very good but has its downside in that it requires stacking before use, essentially skipping your cooldowns on pull. This makes it difficult to recommend for most situations, and it doesn't particularly shine in Mythic+ either.
Improvised Seaforium Pacemaker was one of the strongest trinkets in Season 2 but has gotten nerfed and isn't a must-have anymore.

Algari Alchemist Stone is actually not horrible. While it's not the strongest anywhere, it still serves as a solid and reliable option that can be crafted at any time for those getting unlucky with drops. It generally won't be used because of the cost of a spark, but it's good to keep in mind later in the season.

Subtlety Rogue.note: Is the strongest on-use trinket in our arsenal on any fight that lasts five minutes or longer. The on-use effect has a 20-second cooldown but will only be used every 90 seconds with  Shadow Blades, with the exception of using it during your cooldowns when the fight is about to end before your next  Shadow Blades cast. The use allows both to be put together in a macro.

This trinket has a low cooldown of 120 seconds, but we line it up with our major cooldowns, which means we only use it once every 3 minutes. This opens up the opportunity to combine it with other strong on-use trinkets. The three-minute cooldown fits well with fight lengths below 4 minutes and can make this the best option even as the only active trinket. We use it with  Shadow Blades. The trinket does damage to you on activation so make sure to not use it when on low health.

Mastery is our absolute best stat but the amount of Mastery given is low. This is likely because a lot of the stat budget of the trinket is in the main stat. The trinket is still a very good option and is the only farmable alternative to raid options. The use is fairly simple with  Shadow Blades.

This trinket is the best passive trinket from Raids and the overall best option. Critical Strike is a good stat in a season where stat drs becomes relevant. The trinket spawns orbs you need to collect so it requires some active engagement.
This trinket is the first pure damage trinket. It has a built-in execute, increasing its damage potential slightly on longer fights or fights with damage amplifiers.
This trinket is the best passive option from Mythic+. Critical Strike is our third best stat, but the trinket offers a high amount and it is not that far behind Mastery and Versatility.
Is a solid trinket where the only downside is having no control over the buff you get. This is not that bad because we like Versatility, Mastery, and Critical Strike a lot.
This trinket is good, but becomes noticeably worse with more targets. Having the effect bound to auto attacks means boss uptime is very important to get the best value.

The only crafted option. The main drawback of this trinket is the limitations of crafted gear. It is, early on, better to invest in weapons or embellishments. This gives players a long time to collect competing options.

This trinket takes a bit of housekeeping. It is ideally used on a target with Versatility or Mastery but Critical strike is still a good option. Haste should be avoided. Versatility is usually the highest stats of tanks, which means we should be able to reliably get it even in Mythic+ dungeons.
Haste is sadly not the best stat for us, but the proc chance of the trinket is high enough to still make it a solid option.

The damage of the explosion is solid but we want to ideally collect the orb for the Mastery effect. Doing so is especially important during major cooldowns. It does not matter much outside of cooldowns.
The best delve trinket this season. Mastery is our strongest Secondary stat and killing enemies is a good way to increase the proc rate.

Elemental Shaman.note: Pretty handidly just the strongest trinket in the next patch, on-use or otherwise. The life-loss is kind of annoying but should never put you into any danger. The damage from this trinket first goes into shields so if you combine it with the voidglass set, this becomes a very low-risk/high-reward item. The Critical Strike on it isn't optimal but we need some amount anyway, so we just minimize the Crit we get from gear as much as possible.

The highest damage passive stat trinket. On paper this also beats  Diamantine Voidcore and should definitely be used over the Voidcore if you do not have a voidglass weapon. The "chargeup" is a bit annoying. It's impossible to get the main stat proc on pull. Regardless, this trinket wins purely by numbers.

The highest damage passive stat trinket. On paper this also beats  Diamantine Voidcore and should definitely be used over the Voidcore if you do not have a voidglass weapon. The "chargeup" is a bit annoying. It's impossible to get the main stat proc on pull. Regardless, this trinket wins purely by numbers.

A crowd-favorite trinket from Shadowlands returns. A main-stat stat-stick with a more-or-less freely choosable secondary buff. You can most likely cap out on mastery without this effect and then just find a friend with either haste or versatility as their main secondary stat.

This is the second best on-use trinket we have available this season. Giving mastery on-use is a bit awkward. We need to drop Mastery on other pieces to not completely overcap leaving us with less mastery outside of our burst windows. If you do gear around it, this can get pretty close tho.
Another nice little secondary stat proc trinket. Not much to say here. Equip it, get random secondary stats. Pretty good

Enhancement Shaman.note: While Critical Strike may not be our most desirable stat, this will proc almost guaranteed every minute. This basically makes it an on-use trinket in disguise that lines up with every  Doom Winds for  Totemic, and overlaps with  Ascendance and other on-use effects for  Stormbringer.

While not nearly as strong as  Araz's Ritual Forge, this is still a solid on-use option that  Stormbringer holds for  Ascendance.  Totemic uses this on cooldown with  Primordial Wave, with every other cast  Doom Winds, or can shift its usage around depending on the amount of burst required. Also gains some extra value if other party members are using it.

While passive Versatility isn't very exciting, the proc rate and average uptime of the Primary stat (Agility in our case) means that this is a reasonable pick if you're really struggling to get hold of a good trinket, and have an extra  Spark of Starlight lying around. It is not a priority otherwise, though, and is quickly outpaced by stronger options on this list.

Affliction Warlock.note: Strong effect that you can grant to another party member, benefitting you both, but there are better options that suit Affliction.

Destruction Warlock.note: Strong effect that you can grant to another party member, benefitting you both, but there are better options that suit Affliction.

Protection Warrior.note: This trinket has 2 parts, the default tooltip is only 50% of what it does:Shield Mode:grants armor and magic absorbSword mode:grants crit and huge dmg procAfter you cycle through "50 pages" of either mode by taking damage, it swaps over to the other. You can force this change by using the on-useAfter using the on-use mode you swapped to is doubled for 20 secondsThe goal is generally to stay in sword mode as long as possible for an extremely powerful offensive trinket!
Powerful up-front crit buff every 60 seconds for high damage output for Raid and a good amount of parry for M+!
Our only reliable "on-use" shield trinket this season. Not a fan of the 2-minute cooldown. Receiving damage from damage-over-time effects can reduce this cooldown.
